subject: Ethics
title: Hume's Is-Ought Problem
description: A short lesson to help you apply Hume's Is-Ought Problem.

hook.text: People naturally care for their children. Does that mean they ought to? Watch the gap.

buildup.text: David Hume noticed writers constantly slide from describing what is to prescribing what ought to be.

discovery.text: No pile of facts alone can produce a moral rule. A hidden value judgment always sneaks in.

twist.text: Science can say smoking kills. It cannot say you ought to live‚Äîthat requires a value choice.

climax.text: Hume's guillotine still haunts ethics: every moral argument needs at least one 'ought' premise.

punchline.text: Facts tell you what is. Only values tell you what matters.

quiz.question: What does Hume's is-ought problem claim?
options: Moral rules can be derived purely from scientific facts
Descriptive statements alone cannot yield prescriptive conclusions
